list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Find the value of each of the following, giving your answer as an
integer.


$log10​100$. [2]



$log10​50+log10​2$. [2]



$log10​4−log10​40$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log10​100​=log10​(102)=2log10​10=2​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we find
$$$log10​50+log10​2​=log10​(50⋅2)=log10​100=2​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we obtain
$$$log10​4−log10​40​=log10​(404​)=log10​(101​)=log10​(10−1)=(−1)log10​10=−1​​$$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Find the value of each of the following, giving your answer as an
integer.


$log6​6$. [2]



$log6​9+log6​4$. [2]



$log6​72−log6​2$. [2]
list.markScheme:
$log6​6=1​$


Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log6​9+log6​4​=log6​(9⋅4)=log6​36=log6​(62)=2log6​6=2​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we obtain
$$$log6​72−log6​2​=log6​(272​)=log6​36=2​​$$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Let $log2​a=p$, $log2​b=q$, $log2​c=r$. Write down the
following expressions in terms of $p$, $q$ and $r$.


$log2​(cab​)$ [2]



$log2​(b3a2c​)$
[2]



$loga​b$ [2]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log2​(cab​)​=log2​(ab)−log2​c=(log2​a+log2​b)−log2​c=p+q−r​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we find
$$$log2​(b3a2c​)​=log2​(a2c)−3log2​b=(2log2​a+log2​c)−3log2​b=2p+r−3q​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we obtain
$$$loga​b​=log2​alog2​b​=pq​​​$$$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Let $p=ln2$ and $q=ln6$. Write down the following expressions in
terms of $p$ and $q$.


$ln12$ [2]



$ln3$ [2]



$ln48$ [3]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of natural logarithms, we get
$$$ln12​=ln(2⋅6)=ln2+ln6=p+q​​$$$


Using the properties of natural logarithms, we find
$$$ln3​=ln(26​)=ln6−ln2=q−p​​$$$


Using the properties of natural logarithms, we obtain
$$$ln48​=ln(23⋅6)=3ln2+ln6=3p+q​​$$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Let $a=log5​b$, where $b>0$. Write down each of the following
expressions
in terms of $a$.


$log5​b4$ [2]



$log5​(25b)$ [2]



$log25​b$ [2]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log5​b4​=4log5​b=4a​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we find
$$$log5​(25b)​=log5​(52⋅b)=2log5​5+log5​b=2+a​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we obtain
$$$log25​b​=log5​25log5​b​=2log5​5log5​b​=2a​​​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Consider
$a=log63​64×log62​63×log61​62×⋯×log2​3$.
Given that $a∈Z$, find the value of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$a​=log63​64×log62​63×log61​62×⋯×log2​3=log63​log64​×log62​log63​​×log61​log62​​×⋯×log2log3​​=log2log64​=log2log26​=log2​6log2​​=6​​$$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Write the expression $4ln2−ln8$ in the form of $lnk$, where
$k∈Z$. [3]



Hence, or otherwise, solve $4ln2−ln8=−ln(2x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$4ln2−ln8​=ln(24)−ln8=ln16−ln8=ln(816​)=ln2​​$$$


Replacing the left hand side of the equation with $ln2$, we get
$$$4ln2−ln8ln2−ln2ln(2−1)2x2x​=−ln(2x)=−ln(2x)=ln(2x)=ln(2x)=2−1=21​x=41​​​$$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Solve the equation $log5​x−log5​4=2+log5​3$ for $x$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log5​x−log5​4log5​x−log5​4log5​4x​log5​4x​4x​​=2+log5​3=log5​52+log5​3=log5​(52⋅3)=log5​75=75​$$$
$$$x=300​$$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Given that $loga​2=5$.


Find the exact value of $loga​32$. [2]



Find the exact value of $loga​​2$. [2]



Find the value of $a$, giving your answer correct to $3$ significant
figures. [2]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$loga​32​=loga​25=5loga​2=5(5)=25​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we find
$$$loga​​2​=loga​log2​=21​logalog2​=2loga​2=2(5)=10​​$$$


Using the definition of logarithm, we obtain
$$$loga​2a5a​=5=2=251​​$$$
$$$a≈1.15​$$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Find the value(s) of $x$ when
$27x+2=(91​)2x+4$.

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Solve the equation $log3​x−log3​5=1+log3​4$ for $x$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log3​x−log3​5log3​x−log3​5log3​5x​log3​5x​5x​​=1+log3​4=log3​3+log3​4=log3​(3⋅4)=log3​12=12​$$$
$$$x=60​$$$

list.title: Question 12
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$log2​8​=log2​(23)=3log2​2=3​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$log5​(251​)​=log5​(5−2)=(−2)log5​5=−2​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$log9​3​=ln9ln3​=ln(32)ln3​=2ln3ln3​=21​​​$$$




Hence we get
$$$log2​8+log5​(251​)+log9​33+(−2)+21​23​163/243​=log16​x=log16​x=log16​x=x=x​$$$
$$$x=64​$$$

list.title: Question 13
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$log3​81​=log3​(34)=4log3​3=4​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$log2​(81​)​=log2​(2−3)=(−3)log2​2=−3​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$log25​5​=ln25ln5​=ln(52)ln5​=2ln5ln5​=21​​​$$$




Hence we get
$$$log3​81+log2​(81​)+log25​54+(−3)+21​23​93/233​=log9​x=log9​x=log9​x=x=x​$$$
$$$x=27​$$$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Given that $logb​3=10$.


Find the exact value of $logb​81$. [2]



Find the exact value of $logb2​3$. [2]



Find the value of $b$, giving your answer correct to $3$ significant
figures. [2]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$logb​81​=logb​34=4logb​3=4(10)=40​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we find
$$$logb2​3​=logb2log3​=2logblog3​=21​logb​3=21​(10)=5​​$$$


Using the definition of logarithm, we obtain
$$$logb​3b10b​=10=3=3101​​$$$
$$$b≈1.12​$$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Find the values of $x$ when
$25x2−2x=(1251​)4x+2$.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Solve the equation $log3​(x2−4x+4)=1+log3​(x−2)$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log3​(x2−4x+4)log3​(x2−4x+4)log3​(x2−4x+4)x2−4x+4x2−7x+10(x−2)(x−5)x−5​=1+log3​(x−2)=log3​3+log3​(x−2)=log3​(3x−6)=3x−6=0=0=0[since x−2>0]​$$$
$$$x=5​$$$

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Solve the equation $log2​(x2−2x+1)=1+log2​(x−1)$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log2​(x2−2x+1)log2​(x2−2x+1)log2​(x2−2x+1)x2−2x+1x2−4x+3(x−1)(x−3)x−3​=1+log2​(x−1)=log2​2+log2​(x−1)=log2​(2x−2)=2x−2=0=0=0[x=1, since log2​0]​$$$
$$$x=3​$$$

list.title: Question 18
list.content: Solve $log6​(x)+log6​(x−5)=2$, for $x>5$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log6​(x)+log6​(x−5)log6​(x(x−5))log6​(x2−5x)x2−5xx2−5x−36(x+4)(x−9)x−9​=2=log6​62=log6​36=36=0=0=0[since x+4>0]​$$$
$$$x=9​$$$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Find the value of


$log5​75−log5​3$; [2]



$25log5​8$. [4]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log5​75−log5​3​=log5​(375​)=log5​25=log5​(52)=2log5​5=2​​$$$


Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we obtain
$$$25log5​8​=(52)log5​8=52log5​8=5log5​(82)=5log5​64=64​​$$$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Find the value of


$log7​98−log7​2$; [2]



$49log7​6$. [4]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log7​98−log7​2​=log7​(298​)=log7​49=log7​(72)=2log7​7=2​​$$$


Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we obtain
$$$49log7​6​=(72)log7​6=72log7​6=7log7​(62)=7log7​36=36​​$$$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
The first three terms of a geometric sequence are $lnx9$, $lnx3$,
$lnx$, for $x>0$.


Find the common ratio. [3]



Hence, solve $k=1∑∞​33−klnx=27$.
[5]
list.markScheme:
We have $u1​=9lnx$ and $u2​=3lnx$.
Hence the common ratio is
$$$r​=u1​u2​​=9lnx3lnx​=31​​​$$$


The $n$th term of the geometric sequence is
$$$un​​=u1​rn−1=9lnx(31​)n−1=33−nlnx​$$$
Hence we have
$$$S∞​​=k=1∑∞​33−klnx​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $S∞​=27$ for $x$, we get
$$$1−ru1​​1−1/39lnx​3−127lnx​lnx​=27=27=27=2​$$$
$$$x=e2​$$$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
The equation $e2x−12ex=−32$ has two solutions, $x1​$ and $x2​$.

Find the value of $x1​$ and the value of $x2​$.[5]


A second equation, $2(log9​x)(log3​x)−6log9​x−2log3​x=−6$, also has two solutions, $x3​$ and $x4​$.




Show that this second equation can be expressed as
$$$(log3​x)2−5log3​x+6=0​$$$


Hence find the value of $x3​$ and the value of $x4​$. [7]





Given that $x1​+x2​=a(x3​+x4​)$, find the value of $a$. Give your answer in the form $blnc$, where $b,c∈R$.[3]
list.markScheme:
The equation can be written as a quadratic in $ex$:
$$$(ex)2−12ex+32=0​$$$
The equation can then be factorised:
$$$(ex−4)(ex−8)=0​$$$
From the first bracket, we have
$$$ex−4exx​=0=4=ln4=2ln2​$$$
And from the second bracket,
$$$ex−8exx​=0=8=ln8=3ln2​$$$
Hence, $x1​=2ln2 and x2​=3ln2.​$




We are asked to write the second equation in terms of $log3​x$, and currently the equation is expressed in terms of $log3​x$ and $log9​x$. Using the formula for changing the base, we have
$$$log9​xlog9​x​=log3​9log3​x​=log3​32log3​x​=2log3​3log3​x​=21​log3​x​$$$
Substituting this expression into our original equation, we get
$$$2(log9​x)(log3​x)−6log9​x−2log3​x2(21​)(log3​x)(log3​x)−6(21​)(log3​x)−2log3​x​=−6=−6(log3​x)2−5log3​x+6=0​​$$$


The equation can be factorised as follows:
$$$(log3​x−2)(log3​x−3)=0​$$$
From the first bracket, we have
$$$log3​x−2log3​xx​=0=2=9​$$$
And from the second bracket,
$$$log3​x−3log3​xx​=0=3=27​$$$
Hence, $x3​=9 and x4​=27.​$




We have
$$$x1​+x2​2ln2+3ln25ln2​=a(x3​+x4​)=a(9+27)=36aa=365​ln2​​$$$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
The first three terms of an infinite sequence, in order, are
$2lnx,qlnx,lnx​ where  x>0.$
First consider the case in which the series is geometric.




Find the possible values of $q$.


Hence or otherwise, show that the series is convergent. [3]





Given that $q>0$ and $S∞​=8ln3$, find the value of $x$. [3]



Now suppose that the series is arithmetic.




Show that $q=45​$.


Write down the common difference in the form $mlnx$, where $m∈Q$. [4]





Given that the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence is $lnx5​$, find the value of $n$. [8]
list.markScheme:
Given that the sequence is geometric, we have for the common ratio
$$$r​=u1​u2​​=2lnxqlnx​=2q​​$$$
Similarly,
$$$r2q​2q​2q​q2​=u2​u3​​=qlnxlnx​​=qlnx21​lnx​=2q1​=1q=±1​​$$$


Given that $r=2q​$, and $q=±1$, we have $r=±21​$. Hence $∣r∣<1$.
$In both cases the series converges.​$




Given that $q>0$, $r=21​$.
Using the formula for the sum of an infinite geometric sequence, we~get
$$$S∞​8ln38ln38ln32ln3ln32ln9​=1−ru1​​=1−21​2lnx​=21​2lnx​=4lnx=lnx=lnx=lnxx=9​​$$$




First we find the common difference $d$ as follows
$$$ddd​=u2​−u1​=qlnx−2lnx=(q−2)lnx​$$$
Similarly,
$$$d(q−2)lnx(q−2)lnx(q−2)lnx(q−2)lnxq−22q2q​=u3​−u2​=lnx​−qlnx=lnx1/2−qlnx=21​lnx−qlnx=(21​−q)lnx=21​−q=21​+2=25​q=45​​​$$$


Given that $d=(q−2)lnx$ and $q=45​$, we have
$$$d​=(45​−2)lnxd=−43​lnx​​$$$




Using the formula for the sum of $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence, we get
$$$Sn​lnx5​lnx5/225​lnx5520203n2−19n+203n2−15n−4n+203n(n−5)−4(n−5)(3n−4)(n−5)​=2n​(2u1​+(n−1)d)=2n​(2(2lnx)+(n−1)(−43​lnx))=2n​((4lnx+(−43​)(n−1)lnx))=2n​(4−43(n−1)​)lnx=n(4−43(n−1)​)=4n−43n(n−1)​=16n−3n(n−1)=16n−3n2+3n=0=0=0=0​$$$
The solutions to the quadratic equation are $n=34​$ and $n=5$.
Since $n$ must be an integer, we have $n=5​$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Solve the following equation for $a$
$$$k=a∑a+35​log13​(kk+1​)​=1​$$$
list.markScheme:
First we will unpack the sigma notation.
The smallest value of $k$ is $a$. This value is the increased by $1$ for each subsequent term.
$$$k=a∑a+35​log13​(kk+1​)​=log13​(aa+1​)+log13​(a+1a+1+1​)+log13​(a+2a+2+1​)+...​$$$
This continues until we reach the largest value of $k$ which is $a+35$.
$$$+...log13​(a+34a+34+1​)+log13​(a+35a+35+1​)​(M1)​$$$
If we simplify the fractions and then apply the following log law
$$$loga​yx​​=loga​x−loga​y​$$$
We get
$$$k=a∑a+35​log13​(kk+1​)​=log13​(aa+1​)+log13​(a+1a+2​)+...log13​(a+35a+36​)=log13​(a+1)​−log13​a+log13​(a+2)​−log13​(a+1)​+−log13​(a+2)​+...+log13​(a+36)−log13​(a+35)​​(M1)​$$$
Notice how the terms cancel each other out, leaving only the two $blue$ terms. Recall, from the question, this is equal to $1$.
$$$−log13​a+log13​(a+36)​=1​A1​$$$
We can now solve the equation by rewriting the L.H.S. as a single logarithm
$$$log13​(aa+36​)​=1​$$$
Using the definition of a logarithm, we rewrite the equation into exponential form
$$$aa+36​​=131​A1​$$$
Now we can solve for $a$
$$$a+3612a​=13a=36a=3​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
The arithmetic sequence has the sixth term of $u6​=ln2$ and the eighth term of $u8​=23​ln4$.




Show the common difference is $ln2$.


Find $u1​$.


Hence, show that the sum of $n$ terms is given by $Sn​=(n2−9n)ln2​$. Where $n∈Z+$. [5]





A new function, $f(x)$, is formed using $Sn​$ with the discrete variable $n$ being replaced with the continuous variable $x$, such that $x∈R$. Hence $f(x)=(x2−9x)ln2​$.




Write down the equation of the axis of symmetry of $f(x)$.


Sketch $f(x)$ on the grid below, identify the axis of symmetry and any axis intercepts.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/5f674790-b5af-473c-b8d4-3f746b96c744/q1037.png)




Hence or otherwise, find the minimum value of $Sn​$ in the form $alnb$. Where $a,b∈Z$ [5]





Consider the linear function $g(x)=(6−3x)ln2​$.




Solve $f(x)=g(x)$.


Hence, solve the inequality $f(x)<g(x)$.


Hence or otherwise, find the range of values of $n$ that satisfy $Sn​<g(x)$. [5]
list.markScheme:
As the sequence is arithmetic we can write $u8​=u6​+2d$. Hence
$$$23​ln42d2d​=ln2+2d=3ln(4​)−ln2=2ln2=ln2​...as required​M1A1AG​$$$

We can use $u6​$ to find the first term
$$$u6​ln2u1​​=u1​+5d=u1​+5ln2=−4ln2​​A1​$$$

Using the sum of $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence we can write
$$$Sn​​=2n​(2×−4ln2+(n−1)×ln2)=2n2​ln2−29n​ln2=2ln2​(n2−9n)=(n2−9n)ln2​​...as required​M1A1AG​$$$






Using the axis of symmetry formula, we can write
$$$x​=−2ln2​−9ln2​​x=29​​​A1​$$$


Here is the sketch of $f(x)$ with the desired features identified.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/ff26f159-934a-404d-946c-88a7dab4de40/a1037-1.png)


$Correct intercepts​$ A1 and $axis of symmetry​$ A1.


Using the symmetry of $f(x)$ we can identify the minimum value(s) of $f(x)$ which has integer $x$ coordinates.
Both points are equidistant from the axis of symmetry and they represent the minimum value of $Sn​$.
$$$(M1)$$$
$gap$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/b53d4797-3cc2-48db-9678-27e521c1ec16/a1037-2.png)


We can use the $x−$value from the graph to pick either $n=4$ or $n=5$ as both will yield the same minimum value. This solution will pick $n=4$, hence, the minimum value of $Sn​$ is
$$$S4​​=(42−9(4))2ln2​=−202ln2​=−10ln2​​A1​$$$






Equate the RHS of each function
$$$(x2−9x)ln2​​=(6−3x)ln2​​$$$
Cancel out the factor $ln2​$ and solve for $x$
$$$x2−9x0​=6−3x=x2−6x−6​(M1)​$$$
We can solve this by completing the square.
$$$(x−3)2−9−6x−3x​=0=±15​=3±15​​​A1​$$$


By making a rough sketch of $g(x)$ on the graph we can solve the inequality\


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/e5de3f5e-73f3-4a69-a581-b579611281ae/a1037-3.png)


We can identify the region the $f(x)<g(x)$. Hence
$$$​3−15​<x<3+15​​​A1​$$$


$n$ must be a positive integer and lie entirely within the region identified in part (c)(ii).
We know that $9​<15​<16​$, hence we can identify the minimum and maximum values of $n$.
$$$M1$$$
$gap$
The minimum value must be an integer larger than $3−15​$.
$$$−1<3−15​<0​$$$
The minimum value of $n$ is $1$.
Similarly, the maximum value must be an integer smaller than $3+15​$.
$$$6<3+15​<7​$$$
The maximum value of $n$ is $6$.
Hence
$1≤n≤6​$.
$$$A1$$$
$gap$

list.title: Question 26
list.content: Solve the equation $9x+2⋅3x+1=1$.
list.markScheme:
If we substitute $y=3x$ in the equation $9x+2⋅3x+1=1$, we
have
$$$(3x)2+6⋅3x−1y2+6y−1​=0=0​$$$
Hence, using the quadratic formula, we
get
$$$y​=2(1)−6+62−4(1)(−1)​​[since y=3x>0]=2−6+210​​=−3+10​​$$$
Hence, using the properties of
logarithms, we obtain
$$$3x​=−3+10​​$$$
$$$x=log3​(−3+10​)​$$$

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
Solve the simultaneous equations:
$$$1+2log5​xlog7​(6x−1)​=log5​7y=1+log7​y​$$$
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we rewrite the given equations as
follows.
$$$log5​5+log5​x2log5​5x25x2log7​(6x−1)log7​(6x−1)log7​(6x−1)6x−1​=log5​7y=log5​7y=7y(1)=1+log7​y=log7​7+log7​y=log7​7y=7y(2)​$$$
From the equations (1) and (2),
we obtain
$$$5x25x2−6x+1(5x−1)(x−1)x​=6x−1=0=0=51​ or x=1​$$$
Substituting $x=51​$ into the equation (1), we get
$$$5(51​)251​y​=7y=7y=351​​$$$
Substituting $x=1$ into the
equation (1), we get
$$$5(1)25y​=7y=7y=75​​$$$
Thus, the solutions are
$$$​x=51​,y=351​​x=1,y=75​​​$$$

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
The first two terms of an infinite geometric sequence, in order, are
$$$3log3​x,2log3​x,where x>0.$$$


Find the common ratio, $r$. [2]



Show that the sum of the infinite sequence is $9log3​x$.
[3]



The first three terms of an arithmetic sequence, in order, are
$$$log3​x,log3​3x​,log3​9x​,where x>0.$$$


Find the common difference $d$, giving your answer as an
integer. [3]



Let $S6​$ be the sum of the first $6$ terms of the arithmetic sequence.


Show that $S6​=6log3​x−15$. [3]



Given that $S6​$ is equal to one third of the sum of the
infinite geometric
sequence, find $x$, giving your answer in the form
$ap$ where $a,p∈Z$.
[3]
list.markScheme:
The common ratio is
$$$r​=u1​u2​​=3log3​x2log3​x​=32​​​$$$


Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S∞​=1−ru1​​$, we get
$$$S∞​​=1−2/33log3​x​=1/33log3​x​=9log3​x​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we find
$$$d​=u2​−u1​=log3​3x​−log3​x=(log3​x​−log3​3)−log3​x​=−1​​$$$


Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$Sn​=2n​(2u1​+(n−1)d)$ with
$n=6$, we get
$$$S6​​=26​(2u1​+(6−1)d)=26​(2(log3​x)+(6−1)(−1))=26​(2log3​x−5)=6log3​x−15​​$$$


If we solve the equation $S6​=31​S∞​$ for $x$, we
obtain
$$$6log3​x−156log3​x−153log3​xlog3​x​=31​(9log3​x)=3log3​x=15=5​$$$
$$$x=35​$$$

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
Consider $f(x)=logk​(8x−2x2)$, for $0<x<4$, where $k>0$.
The equation $f(x)=3$ has exactly one solution. Find the value of $k$.
list.markScheme:
If we rewrite the equation $f(x)=3$ in the form $ax2+bx+c=0$,
we have
$$$logk​(8x−2x2)8x−2x20​=3=k3=2x2−8x+k3​$$$
Hence the quadratic function
$q(x)=2x2−8x+k3$ has two equal roots.
Therefore we get
$$$[discriminant of q](−8)2−4(2)(k3)64−8k38−k3k3​=0=0[△=b2−4ac]=0=0=8​$$$
$$$k=2​$$$

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
Solve $log3​​(sinx)−log3​​(cosx)=1$, for
$0<x<2π​$.
list.markScheme:
We have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7f375b41-33b9-4587-922a-02c76aab5a0d/images/2bc01858-af34-4ec1-bef2-2c845c61c439/eea28ea6dc26969cf5c008612e865ae5046a04ef.svg)


Using the properties of logarithms and the right triangle above, we get
$$$log3​​(sinx)−log3​​(cosx)log3​​(cosxsinx​)log3​​(tanx)tanxxx​=1=1=1=3​=3π​+nπ[for n∈Z]=3π​+0[since 0<x<π/2]​$$$
$$$x=3π​​$$$

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
Solve the equation $154a=81a+2$ for $a$. Express your answer in
terms of $ln3$ and $ln5$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get
$$$154a(3⋅5)4a34a⋅54a54aln54a4aln5​=81a+2=34(a+2)=34a⋅38=38=ln38=8ln3​$$$
$$$a=ln52ln3​​$$$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
Find the integer values of $a$ and $b$ for which
$$$a+blog4​7+60log8​14​=0.​$$$
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$a+blog4​7+60log8​14a+2ln2bln7​+3ln260ln14​aln2+2b​ln7+20ln(2⋅7)aln2+2b​ln7+20(ln2+ln7)(a+20)ln2+(2b​+20)ln7​=0=0=0=0=0​$$$
Hence we get
$a=−20​$
and  $b=−40​$

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
Solve the equation $146x=64x+3$ for $x$. Express your answer in
terms of $ln2$ and $ln7$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get
$$$146x(2⋅7)6x26x⋅76x76xln76x6xln7​=64x+3=26(x+3)=26x⋅218=218=ln218=18ln2​$$$
$$$x=ln73ln2​​$$$

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
Show that $log2​3−cos2x​=log4​(3−cos2x)$.
[3]



Hence, or otherwise, solve
$log4​(3sinx)+41​=log2​3−cos2x​$,
for
$0<x<2π​$.[5]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we deduce
$$$log2​3−cos2x​​=log4​2log4​3−cos2x​​=21​log4​4log4​3−cos2x​​=2log4​3−cos2x​[since log4​4=1]=log4​(3−cos2x)​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we deduce
$$$log4​(3sinx)+41​log4​(3sinx)+41​log4​4log4​(3sinx)+log4​2​log4​(32​sinx)32​sinx​=log2​3−cos2x​=log4​(3−cos2x)[by part (a)]=log4​(3−cos2x)[since 41/4=2​]=log4​(3−cos2x)=3−cos2x(1)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $0<x<2π​$, we
find
$$$32​sinx32​sinx2sin2x−32​sinx+2sinxsinxsinx​=3−(1−2sin2x)[by double angle identity]=2+2sin2x=0[rearranging terms to form quadratic]=432​±18−4⋅2⋅2​​=432​−2​​[since sinx=2​]=22​​​$$$
$$$x=4π​​[since 0<x<2π​]$$$

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
Show that $log16​(cos2x+7)=log4​cos2x+7​$.
[3]



Hence, or otherwise, solve
$log4​(10​cosx)=log16​(cos2x+7)$, for
$0<x<2π​$.[5]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log16​(cos2x+7)​=log4​16log4​(cos2x+7)​=2log4​4log4​(cos2x+7)​=21​log4​(cos2x+7)=log4​cos2x+7​​​$$$


Using the double angle formula for cosine, we obtain
$$$log4​(10​cosx)log4​(10​cosx)10​cosx10cos2x10cos2x8cos2xcos2xcosx​=log16​(cos2x+7)=log4​cos2x+7​[by part (a)]=cos2x+7​=cos2x+7=(2cos2x−1)+7=6=43​=23​​[since 0<x<π/2]​$$$
$$$x=6π​​$$$
